meeting_annotations.speaker: Niki Parenteau, NASA Ames
meeting_annotations.transcript: question this topic, you know, how do you distinguish units to abiotic biotic transition? How do you distinguish that? And it is quite difficult.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Andro Rios (Blue Marble Space/NASA Ames)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Back to in terms of um you're talking about detection of this. So if you have like you said, you know, the sea of amino acids, but yet there is an organism that is utilizing it, you know, the abiotic chemistry, you can take those amino acids and just degrade them and just turn them into mush or polymerize them to all random ways. But biology like you said, would take them along a certain, we were talking about this in the last meeting, along a very certain path. So there would be a very distinct way to to to monitor a sample of of some sort of organism, whatever it is, but looking at that chemistry is going to be very conservative, presumably, even if it is eating feeding off the environment of more complex organic compounds. So that's one way, I mean, it's complex, but that's one way that we could um measure that, I guess.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jay Forsythe (he/him)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I mean, I do I do think there are, you know, this is something I've been thinking about a lot lately and I I do think there are ways to differentiate like a like a chain like molecule that is biotic and potentially from what is abiotic, right? And um, you know, like I'm I make abiotic polymers in my lab all the time with my students, that's what we that's what we do, right? And um, you know, like most you know, most of the time they're, you know, even even if you have a really complex mixture of monomers, right? You know, you can you kind of like I think Laurie said this, you kind of get this like statistical distribution of products, right? And um, you know, when you're looking at, you know, like when you're looking at peptides from a biological system, that's not the case, right? And so, and even when you get when you go to a further level, like there when you when you break these molecules apart, you can see differences in their sequences and things like that, right? And so, um, I definitely think there are potential ways to do that, but I I I don't think necessarily that that space has been explored that much yet. I mean, maybe a little bit, but um, not not a ton. I think there's definitely a lot of room there.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Laurie Barge (NASA JPL)
meeting_annotations.transcript: But would it really be statistical? Because, you know, you're I I I'm familiar with like the type of experiments you do and the monomers you start with come out of other reactions that can be directed, for example. And so if if you had a direction applied to the generation of the monomer or like to the mechanism of the polymerization, you might very well get interesting distributions that are not just statistical. And so maybe, you know, you have intermediate versions of this that are not so obvious.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jay Forsythe (he/him)
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's true. Right. And you know, and and not all the, you know, for example, you know, I I go back to amino acids because that's what I that's what I work with the most, right? And so not different amino acids have different reactivities just due to solubility, differences in solubility, differences in sterics. Um, right? And so it's not like all of them react the same amount either, right? Um, but you kind of like you can kind of get it you can actually figure that kind of stuff out, right? And um, you know, that's kind of one of the things that we're trying to do in my lab. But yeah, no I so I mean we're starting at the like amino acid kind of monomer level. We're not necessarily making them, right? We're just putting them in there, right? And so you're right, if you're going to do some type of um kind of like protometabolism where these these are actually products of other processes, then yeah, I agree. I agree with that. And and we're not doing that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Niki Parenteau, NASA Ames
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think I'll just throw this out there. I'm sure you're probably aware of it, but like a classic example, I mean, I work on lipids. so, you know, the distribution of like a Fisher Trope synthesis of carboxylic acids versus biotic um fatty acids or carboxylic acids that maximize it longer chain lengths, that's optimal for um membrane bilayer formation.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Niki Parenteau, NASA Ames
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um so that differences in those patterns may translate to other sort of building blocks. Um, but I wanted to point out we have about 15 or so minutes left. But uh Laurie brought up a good point and again, I just wanted to circle back to that for a couple of seconds again considering this discussion in the broader topic of um life detection or the search for life in the universe.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Laurie Barge (NASA JPL)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Laura, I heard you say earlier um or maybe I'm I'm putting this out there multiple lines of evidence. So you probably have thought very deeply about um different types of measurements um within the context like of a suite of instruments that you would put on a mission. So do you want to say a couple things about that? Sure. So I mean, I kind of think of in some ways origin of life and the mission thought process is a little bit similar because with origin of life you you conceptually break life down into its components and then you got to come up with some way for each of those to to exist without life in order for it to be life because if you define origin of life as say life without RNA, well then, you know, what? So like you basically have to kind of take each part and have abiotic ways and then all together it is life and that's your origin.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Laurie Barge (NASA JPL)
meeting_annotations.transcript: And so like with a mission, you have to detect a bunch of different things in order to make an attempt at a biosignature identification. So it's things like, you know, do we have organic molecules? What kind are they? Carbon isotopes. People look at things like cell motility or imaging. There's atmospheric detection of things that we think are just made by life and it just kind of depends on what your spacecraft constraints are and there's all sorts of technical problems here. But basically it is in some ways similar because if you detect let's say a carbon molecule or molecules or a distribution or a functionality like an autocatalytic reaction or something like that together is it life? Because you know that each one of those can happen abiotically, otherwise you could not have life's origin.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dimitar Sasselov
meeting_annotations.transcript: And so would that uh be a way to kind of focus our summary in the reporting on practical advice to our colleagues who are trying to do this from this session. Uh the existence of multiple boundaries, the fact that you know, it's difficult to to do that in practical terms, but they have to be aware of.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Laurie Barge (NASA JPL)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I like the boundaries concept and it I think removes the need to try to define life to have an origin of life or to detect it.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Betul Kacar
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, and also the I think the generation or creation of certain molecules or certain size of molecules, I don't think they can serve as a sort of a smoking gun as to whether life originated there or has a potential. I think it's important because I I also you know, hearing this sort of looking at the size of the molecules or even the complexity of the molecule that's generated, that alone is not quite an indicator. You can argue that an elephant and an ant has the same complexity. In fact, I think ants are more complex than an elephant. So you know, generation of big molecules or the size themselves are not indicators, but it's more almost about the generation of some sort of persistent behavior um that that is that is present in whatever the locality that is being screened. So from a mission perspective, I don't know how feasible it is to stay put in in in one place and and then just thoroughly analyze what happens over time because you obviously want to see some presence that is again persistent over time. Um, but I don't know about uh that may mean visiting the planet every uh 500 years.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Niki Parenteau, NASA Ames
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dimitar Sasselov
meeting_annotations.transcript: No, but uh it is a very valuable thing uh what we are discussing to my colleagues, the astronomers. There is not another astronomer here, I think today in our session. But uh, you know, we write proposals for, you know, life detection and biosignatures and uh that kind of discussion is always very much more naive and simplified and it is good for them to have that awareness. So I think it's a good focus if we can put it in our uh reporting from this session.
